Message.Title: Yahoo's Stock Takes Aim At $30
Message.Msg: Yahoo (YHOO) now may have a better risk-reward ratio than just a week ago, when it was trading about $2/share lower. I recently wrote an article reviewing certain valuation measures about this company. I also discussed the improvement in the board and my hope that Marissa Mayer would be a transformational CEO. That article was written on Feb. 27 when the stock was $21.16, and YHOO is $23 (pre-open) on March 7, when I am writing this. Yet I am actually more bullish now than then. There are two reasons for this. The main reason stems from a Barron's blog piece: For more go to Seeking Alpha-

Message.Title: FB's Zuckerberg Copies Yahoo Homepage...Even the Color
Message.Msg: Yahoo is clearly the hot stock now in tech. FB may have 1 billion unique visitors, but 90% of them barely even own a cell phone and, sadly, live in poverty all around the globe while Yahoo has 700,000 unique visitors who check their stocks from their homes and offices and automobiles...in other words, and listen to me: Yahoo has 70% of FB's size, but with an AUDIENCE that advertisers want to TARGET BECAUSE THEY HAVE MONEY. They check thier stock, their sports team, real estate...from YAHOO. CEO Mayer will monetize Yahoo quickly because Yahoo has the AUDIENCE ADVERTISERS WANT.

Message.Title: Alibaba may consider U.S. IPO, South China Morning Post reports
Message.Msg: According to the South China Morning Post, Alibaba (ALBCF) may be considering a public listing on the Nasdaq Stock Market. Two sources say senior finance executives at Alibaba yesterday held a discussion with the Beijing-based chief representative in China for Nasdaq OMX.

Message.Title: Alibaba may choose New York over Hong Kong for its hotly anticipated IPO
Message.Msg: According to the territory’s South China Morning Post, China’s largest e-commerce company, Alibaba Group, is discussing Nasdaq (paywall) as the venue for its long-awaited listing. An IPO could value Alibaba at more than $60 billion, making it potentially the biggest tech IPO in history. If the company chooses a US listing, that would be a further blow to the Chinese territory, where the value of IPOs on the stock exchange plummeted to a four year low last year as mainland China’s economic slowdown made investors less interested in allocating cash there.
